inkface.pygame – Pygame Backend¶

module:: inkface.canvas.pygamecanvas – Pygame Canvas Backend¶

synopsis:This module contains Class definitions used for Pygame Canvas Backend

Module Contents¶

class inkface.pygame.PygameFace(svgname)¶

Loads SVG file and creates PygameCanvasElement object from it. These objects can be accessed as members of this Face instance, addressed by the label given to them in Image editor.

clone(curNodeName, newNodeName, new_x=-1, new_y=-1)¶

Clones an existing element of the face to create a duplicate one.

Parameters:
  • curNodeName – name of existing element to be cloned
  • newNodeName – name the new element should have
  • new_x – [optional] x coord of new element
  • new_y – [optional] y coord of new element
class inkface.pygame.PygameCanvas(resolution=(640, 480), caption='Inkface App', framerate=25, flags=0)¶
Parameters:
  • resolution – Dimensions of the canvas
  • caption – Caption of the application window (if supported by platform)
  • framerate – Rate at which to refresh the canvas (frames per second - fps). The canvas spawns an internal thread to do this periodic refresh. If you are not interested in animation in GUI, then you can mention framerate=0 and the extra thread won’t be spawned. In such situation, you will have to manually call paint() method of canvas if you want the canvas to be refreshed.
  • flags – You can pass additional pygame flags that will be passed to pygame.display.set_mode() call.
add(face)¶
Parameter:face – PygameFace instance to add to this canvas. This actually leads to addition of Face’s elements to canvas’s current list of elements.
eventloop()¶
The loop that application should call after it has setup all GUI elements and is ready to handle events from user.
paint()¶
Redraws the canvas
remove(face)¶
Parameter:face – PygameFace instance to remove from this canvas. This actually leads to removal of Face’s elements from canvas’s current list of elements.
stop()¶
Cleans up the canvas (and its internal thread, if applicable).
class inkface.pygame.PygameCanvasElement(svgelem)¶
hide()¶

Hides this element. Warning: There is a difference in semantics of this call, depending on the pygame version.

  • For pygame version < 1.8.x - Calling hide() will disable the call to onDraw handler of it too. The onDraw of this element won’t be called until unhide() is called.
  • For pygame version >= 1.8.x - Calling hide() won’t disable the call onDraw handler of this element. The onDraw handler will still be called during each refresh cycle. You can use it to unhide this element.
refresh(svg_reload=False, sprite_reload=True)¶

Redraws the SVG element’s cairo surface on PygameCanvasElement’s sprite.

Parameters:
  • svg_reload – If underlying SVG should be redrawn. This needs to be true if you have made changes to the SVG node and need the change to reflect on screen
  • sprite_reload – If sprite should be reloaded. There are cases when SVG is changed and reloaded, but only for purposes of getting estimate of final dimensions. In such case the change is not to be reflected on screen. By setting this param to True, one can save time spent in reloading the sprite. This is only for performance improvement purposes. Even if the sprite gets reloaded, the change won’t get reflected until the canvas gets redrawn.
unhide()¶
Unhides this element
